title: Can the Computer, and the Public, do the Metadata Work?
segmentation: Good morning everybody.
Thank you Claire, and for allowing me to speak to you today.
This is about using computational tools and crowdsourcing games to increase metadata and discover ability of digital media collections.
However, full discourse I am not a linguist and I am not a computer scientist.
So this is what I'm going to talk about who we are.
Our project, some specifics about the project, about audio, cataloging, speech to text, results in some crowdsourcing work.
The CL tool outputs of the some of the tools we're working with an additional work that we're hoping to do in the future.
And basically we have a great data set and you guys are the experts that we'd love to work with.
So who we are?
Are we are the American Archive of Public Broadcasting?
It's a collaboration with the Library of Congress in Washington DC.
And W GBH in Boston?
W GBH is Boston's public broadcasting station.
We have radio and television.
We produce a third of the material that goes out on the national network for PBS.
We produce a wide variety of programming from public affairs to history to science, children's programming, arts, culture, drama and how TOS we've been on the air since the 1950s.
Fifty one with radio in 1955 with television, so we have a very deep, long archive.
The American Archives goal is to preserve and make iaccessible significant public radio and television programs.

the American Archive is a digital archive with website at americanarchive.org and users anywhere in the US can access a wide range of historical, public, television and radio programs from the late 1940s to the present, we support content creators and current stewards of the materials and facilitate the use of historic public broadcasting by researchers, educators, students, and others.
As an aggregator of content, the APB hopes to provide a centralized web portal for discovery of public media materials.
The collection is growing at about 25,000 assets.
Every year, accesses for research, educational and informational purposes only, and due to rights restrictions, I portion.
About 35,000 items are available through our online reading room.

Unfortunately, it's only in the United States at the moment we are trying to push those legal boundaries to make it more internationally available, but all 90,000 items are available for on site location research at WGH or at the Library of Congress.
So the project.

This project was a collaboration between W GBH, the Pop Up Archive and the University of Texas at Austin School of Information and it was generously funded by unless the Institute of Museum and Library Services, which is a federal granting agency in the United States.
This was before pop-up archive was acquired by Apple.
So here's our dilemma.
Our challenge.

We have 90,000 digitized TV and radio programs from over 100 stations across the country along with these digital files, we received incomplete metadata records with very little descriptive data about any of the items or any of the content in the programs.
We have limited staff resources to fully catalog these items.
We figured it would take a full time person, about 30 two years to watch everything, spending only 15 minutes per item, cataloging the complete to catalog the complete collection.
All while we're continuing to add about 25,000 items every year.
However, we do need to know what we have.
It helps us determine the rights issues and what we can make accessible, and we need to be able to make it findable for users.
So to do that we currently need to be able to expose the text for search engines and indexers as you all are very familiar with.
So how do we transform this large amount of audio and video into something that's searchable for search engines and indexers?
And how can we transform it as a data set that can be used as a data set?
We are lucky to have some records that have transcripts.
This is from the news hour which I think James Post Joeski mentioned on Monday.
The transcript can be indexed in the terms can be searched.
Those tools are very clear to use and very easy.
It allows for an easy scan of what the item is about.
You can quickly read through the transcript as you all know and you can kind of get a sense of what the content is without having to actually watch it in real time.
And you can tell roughly where in an hour's program content that you might be interested in.
You can zero in on it very quickly.
However, we have a lot of records that have any data, such as this one.
There's no date, there's No title.
All we really know who's the contributing organization.
This one has a little bit more.
We have a date yay.
The good thing about video again is you can scrub through the video and you can sort of see what the content is visually, which is somewhat helpful, but you're not getting any of the audio cues.
With radio you get you don't even get the visual cues.
All you have is the audio and you have to actually listen to it in real time.
So and we have a wide variety of content which just complicates it as a data set.
We have content from locations across the country.
Lots of different speakers, different speech patterns and accents from 40 different states, their politicians, academics, men on the street.
Use the elders, artists, people from the North South East, West, the Midwest.
We have Creole, French Creole, Caribbean Spanish, an Alaskan native languages, and we have music and other non spoken sounds.
So what are we to do?
We thought this would be a great opportunity for us to collaborate with computational tools and computational linguists.
You are the experts.
Here are some of the tools that are available that we can.
They can help us with this specific project we worked with Pop up archive to create speech to text transcripts of the entire collection.
That was 40,000 hours of material and with UTI Texas to analyze the audio to help further identify speakers and sounds.
We used a crowdsourcing game to help correct or fix the transcript.
The computer generated transcripts.
Which hopefully would then further train the tools to improve the output.
I'm going to talk about the audio analysis first.

Hipsters high performance sound technologies for access and scholarship at Beauty, Texas they used to they used identified speaker sound waves to match sound waves found in the collection to identify speakers, music, applause etc.
And they had a sample size of 4000 hours.
We gave them a set of files with identified speakers.

We human identified speakers in specific files, and there was another set of files that we thought might possibly have those speakers to see if the tool could actually match the sound waves and then identify the speakers in those other files.

There were ten national speakers that we identified in the collection that we thought would be potentially in the other files and also possibly useful to people throughout the country for other collection sets.
We were trying to build a database of sound thumbprints.
Only 10, so here are results.
Only 10 speakers were identified after three years, which is not very many over 90,000 items, so we didn't get very much identified.
It's really hard to do.
It takes a lot of computational power.

It took a lot of time just to identify one speaker and translating the work from the research at UT Texas to a tool training for our own catalog was undefined, and we're not sure how we would move forward with this kind of effort.
Speech to text results.
This is a slide.
Actually the Pop up Archive put together to explain their lexecon.
Again, this is out of my wheelhouse.
I'm not a linguist, we're archivists.
We can kind of understand this, but I can't model this, so I need to use the output tools.
The output of these these lexicons.
This is an example of the transcript with named entities that have been identified.
It can pull together the entities into a string that can make sense to identify categories.

We were actually really excited about this, thinking that this might help us define what the content is in our programs, but we're actually not sure all these strings that were identified were necessarily helpful.

For example, this happens to be a presidential election on Halloween, so it identified the word Halloween really in the context of the program, it wasn't that important, so there are a lot of things that are being identified that really aren't necessary.
So brother, not necessarily useful in terms of telling us what's actually in the content.
This is another pop up slide working with the pop-up archives speech to text tools.
This is basically kind of their pipeline and how they worked.
Many of these.
As an archivist, I don't understand a lot of this, just to tell you that.
So this is where there's a bridge that we really need to bridge.
This gap between these two disciplines in order for us to work together effectively.
So the transcript creation continues, even though pop-up archival is bought by Apple.

We now have the GitHub code.
We have the code for quality in GitHub and we're continuing to use it.
We've been document we dockerize the code and now we have it's part of our ongoing workflow as we get new materials into create transcripts.
And this is the GitHub account where the code is existing.

Now we have these great speech to text tools, transcripts.
Experience has shown us that most of these speech detects don't output clean transcripts.
Accurate transcripts are dependent on audio quality, speaker accents, background noise, etc.
Given that our collections from 100 different local TV and radio stations across the country, the variety of audio and radio quality varies widely.
Some of the programs are in Spanish, summer musical performances and nearly all begin with the standard bars and tones.
For video recordings.
The speech to text.
Tries to interpret these sounds as text and it makes a number of other mistakes too.
So we created three tools to allow the public crowdsourcing to help us correct and fix these transcripts.
The first one we use with universe.

The producer names.

You can identify errors in the transcript.
You can suggest fixes in the transcript where you can validate.
Errors in the transcript.

So once the transcripts have been verified, the Jason transcripts will be stored in the apbs Amazon S3 account.

We're hoping that researchers will begin to look at the collection as a data set and start trying to see trends from programming over the last 60 years in similar effects.
The way we present presentation, you just saw.

We've identified some key things for us that it would be really useful, like forced alignment of transcripts, timestamping that bars and tone at the beginning, so we can just skip over that for user experience and identifying music in foreign languages and also identifying text on the screen to OCR for clean method.
We recognize, however, that more work is needed to develop these open workflows and automating metadata creation and improving tools such that they create meaningful output for archives.
Much of this work is old work for you guys, but it's a very new opportunity for us and I'm looking forward to working with all UCL experts and hoping to improve these tools for archives.
